The patient's mechanism of injury suggests a possible medial collateral ligament tear, and the Valgus stress test is the most appropriate exam maneuver to test for ligamentous laxity of the medial collateral ligament. The anterior drawer test and Lachman's test are used to test for anterior cruciate ligament tears, while the pivot shift test is used to test for a posterolateral corner injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury described (hit on the lateral aspect while the right foot was planted) suggests a possible medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The Valgus stress test is used to assess the MCL and will demonstrate ligamentous laxity in this case. The anterior drawer test is used to assess the anterior cruciate ligament, the Lachman's test is used to assess the stability of both the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments, and the pivot shift test is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament. None of these tests are specific for MCL injury.
